Three Ways Small Businesses Can Compete With Big Brands Online

One billion dollars. That’s the minimum annual advertising budget for nearly 40 of the United States’ biggest brands, according to 2015 report by Ad Age.

Compare that to the average SMB, who spends just $4,800 a year on marketing.

Those numbers beg an obvious question: how can small businesses possibly compete with big brands when it comes to web presence, social media, and online marketing?

You might be surprised to discover that small businesses actually have certain advantages over big brands. The secret is knowing how to use them. So as a small business owner, what do you bring to the table that mega corporations can’t compete with?

1) Your Authenticity

Which recipe for chocolate chip cookies would you rather follow?

The recipe from the kindly neighborhood grandmother (who happens to sell her cookies at your local small grocery)?

Or the recipe on the Billsbury brand website (encouraging you to choose Billsbury brand flour, chocolate chips, and cooking spray at every turn)?

When it comes to online marketing, small businesses have the inherent advantage of their authenticity. And (not ironically) they don’t even have to try.

Just by being you, and sharing your experiences and knowledge, you produce content people intrinsically trust.

2) Your Expert Advice

Your customers come to you for expert advice on everything from what shampoo to buy for their hair type to how to choose window treatments for a shabby-chic living room.

Being a small business owner, you’re automatically a subject matter expert. Your motive isn’t to sell more Billsbury brand products, but to remind users they can find the information, products, or services they need in your store (and on your website).

3) Your Local Knowledge

Own a restaurant in the northeast? Then you probably have a seasonal menu. You might even have a few favorite farms from which you source local ingredients. That’s exactly the type of value you can provide your customers that big brands just can’t compete with.

So if you know someone who sells the best fresh crullers this side of Boston (we’re looking at you, Lil’s), or you’ve got a go-to “meat guy” who never lets you down; tell your audience about them!

Plus, it’s got karmic benefits. You’re helping to support other local small businesses—building the symbiotic relationships and positive word-of-mouth that small businesses rely on.

So What Kind of Content Should Small Businesses Produce?

There’s a reason artisan craftsmanship persists, even thrives, in our chain-driven, mass-produced society. People love to admire the work of other people. Small businesses should share content that reminds their audience of the bodies behind the brand.

Sell handmade products? Follow the example set by New Hampshire-based Fancy Face Studios whose gorgeous Instagram account that undoubtedly helps their top-rated business continue to blossom. Post photos of your work, your studio, and your process frequently on Instagram and Facebook.

Make beautiful wedding cakes? Start a blog and share your creations on your Pinterest, along with high-quality photos, recipes, decorating tips, and dessert-related wedding tips you’ve picked up along the way.

In a less romantic industry? That’s okay too. Your audience wants your lawn-care tips and before and after photos. They love your easy dinner recipes and glossy snapshots of your daily specials.

In short, give your audience a peek at your products, your story, and your expertise. Remember why your clients come to you and share with them what you know best. Trust us, they’ll thank you for it.
